meta_data.title: Wrestling with the Problem of Evil – Listener Feedback

transcription_data.text: Welcome to Reconstructed Faith, a podcast where we talk about truth you can build your life on. We hope to dive into the hard conversations of life and faith and seek out reasonable, substantive answers. My name is Colson Lechner, and I'm joined by Chris Legg and Bryn Starnes. This is Reconstructed Faith. Welcome back to the Reconstructed Faith podcast. My name is Colson Lechner alongside my partners in crime, Chris Legg and Bryn Starnes. Guys, it's good to be back together. And today we are going to start off our conversation with responding with some feedback that we've gotten in person. And we were just discussing right before we started recording some other topics that we can jump into. So we're kind of, if you've been listening fairly regularly or to our most recent episodes, we're talking a lot about deconstruction and deconstructors. We've also been talking about the state of the church and this whole phenomenon of de-churching. Chris, well, I guess we're all kind of in our own speed listening to or reading through the great de-churching book. And so there's been some good conversations that have come from that. And so I'm going to throw it over to Bryn to get us started with some of the conversations that you were having that you thought could lead to some good dialogue. Yeah, so there are several that I think would be really helpful to revisit a little bit and clarify and even unpack. But the first one, just kind of in order of how they were posted, was a follow-up question about the debrief of Catherine Covington's interview, which I thought was really helpful. And this was actually from a couple of people. Just the last part that we covered talking about the problem of evil and suffering and kind of the integration of God being all-knowing and all-powerful in that question. So we had several people ask us to clarify what we meant by the role and what we think is biblical when it comes to the role of God in specifically what He causes. So we talked about how He allows a lot of bad things to happen to His followers. And there's, I know we've covered the problem of evil and suffering before, but just kind of in a new way to talk about it more specifically with this context of, okay, we know that God does allow bad things to happen. And He, as His character, is redemptive and He is the Redeemer. He redeems those bad things for His glory and for His good. It doesn't mean that He makes them good. It means that He uses them for the good of that person and His kingdom. But I think specifically the question was, okay, but when it comes to evil, specifically when it's something that is sin or we would classify as evil, what does it mean that God allows it? And we know that God does cause some things in the world to happen, but were we saying that He causes evil or sin or something in someone's life that even if it's for a good end, even if it's for redemptive end, would we go that far? And I think that was kind of where maybe we weren't as clear as we meant to be, and several people asked for clarification. So all that to say, that was a good question for me to process. I was telling both of you guys before we started recording just the, I think that's a good question that I may not have asked myself in that way. Like I think I've wrestled through the problem of evil and suffering a lot, but when it comes to the question, and Chris, I'm curious what your thoughts are, but specifically when it comes to, okay, we know that God is all powerful and can cause things to happen, but would we say that He causes things to happen if they are like sin or evil? Because I think from what my understanding of the character got, the character of God, we would say that's not accurate, but it's nuanced and complex. I understand. So yeah, what are your thoughts? Just kind of as a follow up to our conversation about that. Yeah. Let me ask, let me ask first. So when we're talking about evil here, I assume that what you're or what's being asked is about moral evil, right? Yes. Someone who is a moral free agent doing something evil, right? That would be classified as sin. Would God cause someone to do something that, cause it's since sin is a little tougher because sin is not, and we'll discuss this about evil here in a second, but you know, sin is not purely just behavioral. Like something that could be a sin under some conditions could also not be a sin under another condition. A famous example is, you know, typically speaking, lying is sinful. But there's great debate on would it be lying to lie to German officers coming to take the Jews that you have hiding in your house, like, or the way that, you know, we're supposed to obey the government, but we don't obey the government if the government commands us to, for example, stop worshiping God. And so, and so there's a, there's, you know, we're not saying that, you know, that morals are just purely, you know, situational, but you also can't purely pull situation away from morality, obviously. So I think that's pretty obvious probably to most people. And so it's not always an easy question. However, let's, let's, let's focus in on this idea of, of moral evil. Would God cause me, instruct me, either one of those, can it be either one instruct or cause me to do something that is morally evil? I mean, I, I mean, I go back to James one, as far as like James one 13 says, let no one say when he is tempted, I'm being tempted by God for God cannot be tempted with evil. And he himself tempts no one, but each person is tempted when he is lured and enticed by his own, excuse me, lured and enticed by his own desire. Right. So yeah, that's one of the things I'm thinking of. And I know that that at least when you, what we've been talking about a lot with, because in our church, Chris has been teaching through first Samuel and the Bible records, just because the Bible records sin or evil that happens, that doesn't mean that God condones it or, but are so, but am I getting off of, am I getting a little off track? Because it's like, I, I think you can say that God permits these things to happen. Right. But that's, that's easy. Right. I don't think anyone, I mean, I'm sure there are people who struggle with it. Go ahead. Or are you saying that I was just going to say, I think it's very related, Colson, because, you know, if, if scripture says that he doesn't tempt anyone to sin, then logically would follow. He also doesn't cause people to sin in my mind. Right. But if that's the case, there's where our kind of natural question begins to then come in. Yeah. Which is, okay, you say that, but then God tells Saul to wipe out the Amalekites. And so, oh, so then you're like, so what do you mean by sin? So either it is not a sin for Saul to wipe out the Amalekites or God told Saul to sin. And both seem very troubling, don't they? I mean, both seem like, okay, so wiping out a city full of people, whatever that means. And we've, we have unpacked that in other podcasts that part of the language there is something we have to always keep in mind. But because he, you know, the, the Amalekites were not wiped out. And clearly that was an understood thing in that, that, that this is war. There's a certain war language that's going on that we come back to, I've come back to over and over again, the analogy of if I tell the, you know, if I tell my little league baseball team, I'm like, guys, you just, you gotta just destroy these guys. I mean, I want you to just, just wipe them out. None of those kids are probably going to show back up, you know, ready for war. They think, I mean, baseball. And so exactly. And so in this situation, Saul and whoever was there guiding Saul knew what God meant by wipe them out, which apparently meant defeat them, not literally to kill every single one of them. So that's, I'm not, I'm not simplifying that. That's just, that's one of the things we've talked about already several times is that that you've got to be aware of the type of literature that you're reading when it comes to stuff like that. Now, I want to go back though to the bigger picture because here's where I start this conversation. This is where I always start the conversation because it seems to me like the root of this conversation is did God create evil? If, if there is nothing and then God creates and later there is evil, how do you get away from the idea that God created evil? It sure seems like there wasn't any evil and then God created things. And then later there is evil. How is it not that God created evil? Yeah. And, and my beliefs on this and, and my beliefs on this is that there is no such thing as evil. Um, evil is a descriptor used to describe the lack of something good. Um, it's not a thing. It's like two that you don't say there is, there's such a thing as two. And I would say no, we use two to describe the frequency of something being in existence. There are two of them, but there's no such thing as two, or you might say there's no such thing as cold. Which God created light, but it doesn't say he created darkness, right? It says the earth was dark and then he created light. Yeah. Formless and without void. Well, that's something. No, it's not. Chaos is the opposite of something in their thinking, which again, we don't, that's tough for us. And so we go, well, you have to have something to have order or chaos. And they would say, no, chaos is the opposite of something. And then when they, the, when they chose the opposite of, or not the opposite, but the absence of good. Is that how you would say it? Anything other than God's and CS Lewis is famous for this. Um, and, and I think he makes a very compelling case in mere Christianity that that is correct. Um, no, I just was going to say, I think that is such a good point because one of the things that I think we've talked about in the past, but I think often our culture leans so heavily into even empathy, like beyond sympathy, just empathy for people that it takes away. It tries to take away any place for someone to speak truth into someone else. But then I think sometimes we go to the opposite extreme in the church where we feel the burden to speak truth and to, um, speak truth about who God is and even, even truth that we feel like we'll fix things or somehow make it better. And not that there's not a place for that. Like you're saying, we are called to speak the truth and love, but when it comes to something hard that people are going through, I think sometimes we skip the, just listening and sitting with people. And, um, and we skip to the fixing of, like you're saying, we even try to fix the emotion and in our, in our week, sometimes, um, you know, way of lacking discernment, we skip to speaking truth in a way that, that isn't filled with wisdom. And, and we don't go to the Lord to ask us or ask him like, Lord, give me wisdom in this situation. Help me to know when to speak and when to listen. We just immediately assume, well, I need to speak the truth and, or I need to help fix this emotion. And, and I think there's a lot of damage that has been done by believers who have spoken the truth, but, but without wisdom or discernment that's coming from the Lord, they're doing it in their own strength. And I think that, that does a lot of harm to people specifically who are, are going through hard things, but that's just a thought I had while you were talking. Yeah, I agree with that. I think that's a real, a real issue that we have. And, and none of this, so again, we've said it, none, none of these conversations, even when we can rationally wrap our brains around the idea that there are conditions under which these things could be okay and could carry with them great positive in the long run. Yeah. That doesn't mean that it's not really hard and that it's not, not always, you know, jumping to the logical coherence of an argument is not always going to be the most helpful. But I, I will tell you, I, this, what we were just saying a minute ago, I would love, love for us to be known even in the church as people who don't see emotions as something meant to guide, to dictate truth or to, to be not, not ultimate guide. They don't dictate truth and they aren't something that has to be fixed, therefore. And so if, if, and again, I really feel like that's what I see in scripture is that people have the emotions and they don't feel like it has to be fixed. And they, they just, they turn in the midst of their emotion, they turn to the Lord. And, and so when, when I'm excited, then I can, you know, shout to the Lord. And when I am despairing, then I can call on the Lord. And it's kind of like, again, the example in, in, uh, that we see in the first Corinthians 12 and Romans 12 about, you know, with the, with the body of Christ, when, when we are, when we rejoice, we all rejoice. And when we suffer, we all suffer. Like, again, it's not like we're pretending like we're not supposed to be somehow pretending like, well, we're never going to suffer. Like, no, no, none of these, is that the case? That's part of why we're here. Cause we know we will. So, um, yeah. And, and here's the deal. So I always feel like at the end of this conversation, you've got someone who's going to say, it just shouldn't be this hard. It just shouldn't be this hard to understand this. Like, this should be just, this should be simple. And one, the part of why I'm a Christian is because the Christian answer is not some simple answer because I don't think that would reflect reality. Now, I don't know why God did it the way He did it. And that's something that I am happy to acknowledge. Why didn't He start with this new heaven and new earth that He's going to create someday where, where there is freedom without sin. And there is, you know, there is, there are these things, if that's a correct understanding. And the answer is, I don't know. Maybe it has to do with the fact that He wanted us to, He wanted to be able to teach us the concept of redemption. That, that that was so important to Him for us to see that He loves us so much, He would redeem us. That He had to give us the opportunity to rebel first so that He could then redeem us. But that's supposition. I don't, I don't know. I don't know why God did it the way He did it. Um, I do trust that He knows what He's doing, even when I don't understand it. And that is a step that I understand that some people are going to have a hard time taking. Yeah, yeah, totally. There you go. Sweet. Great. Well, I know that there's, I mean, I'm sure there is more that we will eventually talk about on this topic. If you have any questions, um, regarding this topic, regarding the problem of evil, obviously, we've done other podcasts on that. But if there's something you're like, you know what, I just have this nagging question and I, I would love for somebody to discuss it. Please shoot us an email or a text if you're close to us or just stop us if you see us. Yeah, exactly. Yeah. Thanks for listening. Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith. If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.

And totally, you know, right? Yeah. Good. Clarifying
what, you know, whether or not that is true. And so not, not saying, well,
don't tell the truth. Don't do that. Obviously we talk about, you know,
telling the truth in love with gentleness, right? But, you know, for speaking the truth in love,
speaking the truth in love. Exactly. That's maturity is the ability to speak the truth in love.
So from your perspective, Chris and Bren, you can chime in as well, but we're, when I, when I
consider what Catherine was saying about the grief of losing a loved one. And, and then people just
coming up with pithy things. Yeah. What, because of what we know about God, you know, and, and,
and it could be grief walking through something evil that has happened, you know, people who are
grieving somebody who has been murdered or whatever. What are, for our listeners who,
you know, who are maybe going through something now or walking through a season with somebody who's,
you know, I just think of, you know, really hard situations when it's like you have young kids and,
and one of the parents is ill, you know, diagnosed with something that is really hard.
What, how do you counsel those people? Because I think it would be valuable for people who are
believers listening to hear, okay, these are the people who know the truth and this is how we can
come alongside other people. And then for somebody who's like, I'm really skeptical, but has maybe
heard some pithy responses to hear maybe some more just compassionate responses to, to those things.
Cause we're not saying it cause what I'm hearing you guys saying is it doesn't mean that these
things aren't hard and emotions aren't there and that these, these don't feel evil and an attack.
And sometimes it can feel like God is attacking you. That is not, you know, that's the, an emotive
response. Absolutely. And so what are, and that's not unique. I think most humans, most humans,
if we're willing to be honest about it, have felt that we have, we have asked that question. Where
are you? Right. And, and I, I don't think that's, um, I don't think there's anything inappropriate
about that. Again, I'm trying to take that from the modeling of scripture. I know that, like we've
said, not everything that's in the scripture is proscriptive. It's not something we're supposed to
do, but, but I think, I think the, the, the, the honesty of these psalmists and others, um, even
Jesus himself, you know, that you would say, yeah, I'm, where are you? I don't, I'm not,
I don't sense your presence. I don't see your hand. I don't think you're working. Um, I think
most of us have, have felt that. I mean, I certainly have. Um, and, and so feeling it
and, and knowing the truth, those don't cancel each other. Yeah. Yeah. It's not like these are
mutually exclusive. Gosh, I wish my feelings only connected with what I do to be true. That'd be
cool. Um, but that doesn't apply to any other area of my life. I would suddenly apply here,
that my, of course I feel that, and as a loving friend, I'm more than happy for someone to talk
through what they're feeling and, and to listen to them talk about what they're feeling and,
and to hear that and experience that. And, and even to one degree or another, join them in that.
Um, I mean, I, I have certainly been frustrated at God on behalf of someone else when they tell
me about their life experience. And I'm thinking, where were you? Where were you God? I don't,
I don't get this. This, this one seems like one that you should have stepped in on.
Now I'm not actually trying to call him into account. I don't think I have that authority
or right. You know, that I, again, I think my, I see myself as like a, you know, someone standing
over a surgeon going, ah, you shouldn't have cut that. Like I know that I don't have the position
or the understanding, but, but that doesn't mean I can't feel it. Right. Um, and that I don't think
it. And so I don't see any reason to hide that in the midst of, of in, in the end, you know,
I was, I was quoting to, uh, my daughter last night, Psalm 56, I think it's verse three that says,
when I am afraid, I will trust in the Lord. I mean, I love that. It's like, there's nothing about,
I will stop being afraid. Like when I'm afraid, I will trust in the Lord. That's, um, the assumption
is not the lack of fear. That's right. Yeah. It's, it's a, I am afraid. I do feel isolated.
I do feel alone. Yeah. And my, so I turned to him asking him to let me experience something different.
But, but when it comes to our emotions, I don't know that he promises that this side of eternity.
I think someone can feel alone or feel isolated or feel afraid. And that doesn't make him a liar.
Now, again, I go back to like, I wish he would do it differently, but I don't understand. I don't
understand well enough to know why he would allow certain things and not allow certain things. Um,
so you're saying when it comes to that, well, sorry. So when you're saying when it comes to people
coming to you with hard things in their life, like sitting with them in the emotion of it
and hearing their story would be your first, your first response.
I don't, I don't think our bad emotions are necessarily something that need to be fixed.
And I think that's something that'd be really cool if, if Christians could understand better
is that emotions, even uncomfortable emotions aren't something that have to be changed.
Me being afraid doesn't mean I need to figure out how to not be afraid.
Like that's not, that's not, I need to feel, I may need to feel afraid. Um, of course I want those
to eventually go away, but I'm not, I'm not under the belief that somehow the fact that I feel
afraid is a sin that I need to stop, stop sinning. Um, and I think I may just be feeling afraid and I
need to figure out why I feel afraid. And maybe I have some belief systems that are untrue or unkind
or, um, even faults in which case, yeah, I need to learn how to change those. I need to believe,
you know, one of my goals is to believe the truth. I think that's good for all of us to have that as
a goal and to not believe things that aren't true. Um, so yeah, I would, I think we'd listen.
I think we, we sit with, we sit there with people knowing that there, there is something that they
can trust in that is true. Um, and we can wait until the moment is appropriate to talk about that
side of this as well. Those again, because we don't believe they cancel each other out.
Mm hmm.
I think if you believed they cancel each other out, you would have to be really afraid of that.
But going, yeah, I'm afraid and I trust in the Lord. Yeah.
Those, I don't see those as contradictory.
So speaking of contradictions, then, well, can I say one more thing before you jump?
No, go for it, right? Um, well, I just, I think that's, no, such a good segue.
I just had one more thought.
I'm going to edit this part out anyway.
Um, no, I just was going to say, I think that is such a good point because
one of the things that I think we've talked about in the past, but I think
often our culture leans so heavily into even empathy, like beyond sympathy, just empathy
for people that it takes away. It tries to take away any place for someone to speak truth
into someone else. But then I think sometimes we go to the opposite extreme in the church where
we feel the burden to speak truth and to, um, speak truth about who God is and even,
even truth that we feel like we'll fix things or somehow make it better. And not that there's not
a place for that. Like you're saying, we are called to speak the truth and love, but when it
comes to something hard that people are going through, I think sometimes we skip the, just
listening and sitting with people. And, um, and we skip to the fixing of, like you're saying,
we even try to fix the emotion and in our, in our week, sometimes, um, you know, way of
lacking discernment, we skip to speaking truth in a way that, that isn't filled with wisdom. And,
and we don't go to the Lord to ask us or ask him like, Lord, give me wisdom in this situation.
Help me to know when to speak and when to listen. We just immediately assume, well,
I need to speak the truth and, or I need to help fix this emotion. And, and I think there's a lot
of damage that has been done by believers who have spoken the truth, but, but without wisdom
or discernment that's coming from the Lord, they're doing it in their own strength. And I think that,
that does a lot of harm to people specifically who are, are going through hard things, but that's
just a thought I had while you were talking. Yeah, I agree with that. I think that's a real,
a real issue that we have. And, and none of this, so again, we've said it, none, none of these
conversations, even when we can rationally wrap our brains around the idea that there are conditions
under which these things could be okay and could carry with them great positive in the long run.
Yeah.
That doesn't mean that it's not really hard and that it's not, not always, you know, jumping to
the logical coherence of an argument is not always going to be the most helpful. But I,
I will tell you, I, this, what we were just saying a minute ago, I would love, love for us to be known
even in the church as people who don't see emotions as something meant to guide, to dictate
truth or to, to be not, not ultimate guide. They don't dictate truth and they aren't something that
has to be fixed, therefore. And so if, if, and again, I really feel like that's what I see in
scripture is that people have the emotions and they don't feel like it has to be fixed.
And they, they just, they turn in the midst of their emotion, they turn to the Lord. And,
and so when, when I'm excited, then I can, you know, shout to the Lord. And when I am despairing,
then I can call on the Lord. And it's kind of like, again, the example in, in, uh, that we see
in the first Corinthians 12 and Romans 12 about, you know, with the, with the body of Christ, when,
when we are, when we rejoice, we all rejoice. And when we suffer, we all suffer. Like,
again, it's not like we're pretending like we're not supposed to be somehow pretending like, well,
we're never going to suffer. Like, no, no, none of these, is that the case? That's part of why we're
here. Cause we know we will. So, um, yeah. And, and here's the deal. So I always feel like at the end
of this conversation, you've got someone who's going to say, it just shouldn't be this hard.
It just shouldn't be this hard to understand this. Like, this should be just, this should be simple.
And one, the part of why I'm a Christian is because the Christian answer is not some simple
answer because I don't think that would reflect reality. Now, I don't know why God did it the way
He did it. And that's something that I am happy to acknowledge. Why didn't He start with this
new heaven and new earth that He's going to create someday where, where there is freedom without
sin. And there is, you know, there is, there are these things, if that's a correct understanding.
And the answer is, I don't know. Maybe it has to do with the fact that He wanted us to,
He wanted to be able to teach us the concept of redemption. That, that that was so important to
Him for us to see that He loves us so much, He would redeem us. That He had to give us the
opportunity to rebel first so that He could then redeem us. But that's supposition. I don't,
I don't know. I don't know why God did it the way He did it. Um, I do trust that He knows what He's
doing, even when I don't understand it. And that is a step that I understand that some people are
going to have a hard time taking. Yeah, yeah, totally. There you go. Sweet. Great. Well,
I know that there's, I mean, I'm sure there is more that we will eventually talk about on this topic.
If you have any questions, um, regarding this topic, regarding the problem of evil, obviously,
we've done other podcasts on that. But if there's something you're like, you know what,
I just have this nagging question and I, I would love for somebody to discuss it. Please shoot us
an email or a text if you're close to us or just stop us if you see us. Yeah, exactly. Yeah. Thanks
for listening. Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith. If you enjoyed
what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info at
southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church.
Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
